com.zaxxer.nuprocess
Class NuAbstractProcessHandler

java.lang.Object
  com.zaxxer.nuprocess.NuAbstractProcessHandler
All Implemented Interfaces:
NuProcessHandler
public abstract class NuAbstractProcessHandler
extends Object
implements NuProcessHandler

Convenience base class for a NuProcessHandler with default methods that can be overridden.

Author:
Brett Wooldridge

Method Detail

onStart

public void onStart(NuProcess nuProcess)
This method is invoked when you call the ProcessBuilder.start() method. This is your opportunity to store away the NuProcess instance, possibly in your listener, so that it can be used for interaction within other callbacks in this interface.

Specified by:
onStart in interface NuProcessHandler
Parameters:
nuProcess - the NuProcess that is starting

onExit

public void onExit(int statusCode)
This method is invoked when the process exits. This method is also invoked immediately in the case of a failure to launch the child process.

There are two special values, besides ordinary process exit codes, that may be passed to this method. A value of Integer.MIN_VALUE indicates some kind of launch failure. A value of Integer.MAX_VALUE indicates an unknown or expected failure mode.

Specified by:
onExit in interface NuProcessHandler
Parameters:
statusCode - the exit code of the process, or a special value indicating unexpected failures

onStdout

public void onStdout(ByteBuffer buffer)
This method is invoked when there is stdout data to process or an the end-of-file (EOF) condition has been reached. In the case of EOF, the buffer parameter will be null; this is your signal that EOF has been reached.

You do not own the ByteBuffer provided to you. You should not retain a reference to this buffer. It is required that you completely process the entire contents of the buffer when it is passed to you, as it's contents will be completely overwritten immediately upon receipt of more data without regard for position or limit.

Exceptions thrown out from your method will be ignored, but your method should handle all exceptions itself.

Specified by:
onStdout in interface NuProcessHandler
Parameters:
buffer - a ByteBuffer containing received stderr data, or null signifying that an EOF condition has been reached

onStderr

public void onStderr(ByteBuffer buffer)
This method is invoked when there is stderr data to process or an the end-of-file (EOF) condition has been reached. In the case of EOF, the buffer parameter will be null; this is your signal that EOF has been reached.

You do not own the ByteBuffer provided to you. You should not retain a reference to this buffer. It is required that you completely process the entire contents of the buffer when it is passed to you, as it's contents will be completely overwritten immediately upon receipt of more data without regard for position or limit.

Users wishing to merge stderr into stdout should simply delegate this callback to NuProcessHandler.onStdout(ByteBuffer) when invoked, like so: 

    public void onStderr(ByteBuffer buffer) {
       if (buffer != null) {
          onStdout(buffer);
       }
    }
Notice that a null check is performed. If you merge streams in this way, and you do not check for null here, then your NuProcessHandler.onStdout(ByteBuffer) method will be called twice for an EOF condition; once when the stdout stream closes, and once when the stderr stream closes. If you check for null as above, your NuProcessHandler.onStdout(ByteBuffer) method would only be called once (for the close of stdout).

Specified by:
onStderr in interface NuProcessHandler
Parameters:
buffer - a ByteBuffer containing received stderr data, or null signifying that an EOF condition has been reached

onStdinReady

public boolean onStdinReady(ByteBuffer buffer)
This method is invoked after you have expressed a desire to write to stdin by first calling NuProcess.wantWrite(). When this method is invoked, your code should write data to be sent to the stdin of the child process into the provided ByteBuffer. After writing data into the buffer your code must flip the buffer before returning.

If not all of the data needed to be written will fit in the provided buffer, this method can return true to indicate a desire to write more data. If there is no more data to be written at the time this method is invoked, then false should be returned from this method. It is always possible to call NuProcess.wantWrite() later if data becomes available to be written.

Specified by:
onStdinReady in interface NuProcessHandler
Parameters:
buffer - a ByteBuffer into which your stdin-bound data should be written
Returns:
true if you have more data to write immediately, false otherwise
